title: Woman didn't get job because she asked a common question
text:
Woman didn't get job because she asked a common question Well this is incredibly awkward Share "I am passionate about sales" (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Job interviews are nervy times, as are the days leading up to them. 
A young woman from Winnipeg, Canada, didn't even get to hers. Taylor Byrnes' interview was abruptly cancelled by the company she was looking to work for after she asked an entirely reasonable question. 
Taylor simply enquired about the salary. 
This is an awkward question, but one that is totally fine to ask. If you're going for a job, you've got to know how much you're going to be paid. Please don't say that your biggest fault is being a perfectionist (Photo: Getty) Read More The simple thing you shouldn't do when flying if you want a free upgrade 
Taylor tweeted about the situation. She was going for a menu development job at food delivery service SkipTheDishes. 
She had a successful phone interview and was called into meet the team. Before going in, Taylor emailed to ask about 'wages and benefits'. HR swiftly told her that her second interview wasn't going to happen. 
“Your questions reveal that your priorities are not in sync with those of SkipTheDishes,” Taylor's email reveals. 
Taylor was told that the company believes “in hard work and perseverance," rather than “focusing on compensation." 
It seemed that SkipTheDishes felt Taylor's priorities were wrong and she'd mentioned money too early on in the stages of candidacy. 
“Our company culture may be unique in this way, but it is paramount that staff display intrinsic motivation and are proven self-starters,” the email added. 
Taylor called for a boycott of SkipTheDishes. Many agree that she was treated unfairly. Interviews are tough (Photo: Getty) Read More Customer calls out Sainsbury's over 'suspicious' slogan 
SkipTheDishes has since apologised to Taylor and offered a second interview. 
“The email sent to Taylor was wrong and does not represent our team’s approach or values,” co-founder Joshua Simair said in a public statement. 
“We are very disappointed in how it was handled. We do share a compensation package prior to hiring. As soon as we became aware of it on Monday, we reached out to Taylor to apologize for the email and reschedule her interview.” 
Joshua added that the company is going to provide additional training to staff to avoid similar situations unfolding in future interview scenarios. poll loading Do you think Taylor asked about money too early on? 0+ VOTES SO FAR No, it's fine to ask after a phone interview No, but she probably should've just asked on the phone Yes, it was a bit hasty, she should've waited until the second interview Yes, wait until the job offer Like us on Facebook
